computer.description:
The Lynx 48 was a competitor of the Sinclair Spectrum and the Oric 1. It was a good machine but its main problem was a lack of software. Several models were available with 48 KB, 96 KB or 128 KB RAM, and it was possible to reach 192 KB with on-board RAM expansions! There is even a monitor in the Lynx's ROM which allowed the user to write and edit programs written in machine code.
The 96 KB and 128 KB versions featured 4 KB of additional ROM memory (mirrored twice for obscure reasons) with lots of extra commands for sound effects, such as laser and klaxon, and for using 24 KB of dedicated RAM as data space.
The Lynx Basic has really cool features, unseen on other systems of its category, like REPEAT-UNTIL and WHILE-WEND statements, and automatic indenting of procedures! The graphic possibilities were excellent, especially with the 128 KB model, and CP/M could be used with the optional 5.25" disk-drive and 96 KB or better models.
However, the Lynx had no great success outside Great Britain. The designer of the Lynx is John Shireff, an ex-drummer.
Some hardware devices on the bus had potentially contentious outputs. This meant that you had to be quite brave if you wanted to program in assembly language - if you made a mistake, you could damage the hardware itself. This was highlighted in the user manual!
Camputers ceased trading in 1984. Several companies expressed an interest in buying the business, and in November, 1984, a firm called Anston Technology took over. A re-launch was planned but never happened, and in June, 1986 Anston sold everything - hardware, design rights and thousands of cassettes - to the National Lynx User Group. The group planned to produce a Super-Lynx but was too busy supplying spares and technical information to owners of existing models, and the project never came into being.
_________
Contributors: John J. Diamond (editor), Richard Hince

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX RANGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Three computers of the Lynx range</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX RANGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apart from the Lynx label, the Lynx 48, Lynx 96 and Lynx 128 are exacly alike on the outside.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • TV UHF video output<br> • RGB video output<br> • Monochrome composite video output and Light pen input<br> • Serial RS232 port<br> • Cassette recorder In/Out<br> • Expansion port, main ly used by the floppy disk unit<br> • Power input from the external PSU</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX LABELS</strong></font><br><blockquote>On top: Kynx 96 label<br> On bottom: Lynx 128 label with handwritten serial number.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX IN BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Nicolas Sapin</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX IN USE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The game played here is a PacMan clone called Gobble Spook</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX 96'S NEURONS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Lynx 48 and Lynx 96 share the same main board but with a different RAM and ROM memory layout.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Motorola 6845 display controller, in text and graphics modes<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Rarely used I/O chip, the Intersil LM64021, compatible with the more common 6821 chipset. Manages almost all of the system ports.<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 24 KB BASIC ROMs (3x2764). The Lynx 48 board only has 16 KB of ROM memory (2 IC and an empty socket)<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Z80A CPU, here a Sharp version<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> 64 KB RAM chips (8x4164), replaced with 16 KB chips (8x4116) in the Lynx 48<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 16 KB expansion card. A third bank of 16 KB is soldered on the main board<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Internal connector connected in parallel with the external expansion connector.<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX 128, MORE NEURONS...</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Lynx 128's mainboard was completely redisigned to afford larger RAM capacity.<br><br> <b><font color="#666666">(1)</font></b> Three 8 KB EPROM chips hold the same 24 KB BASIC and monitor as the Lynx 96<br> <b><font color="#666666">(2)</font></b> Zilog Z80A microprocessor<br> <b><font color="#666666">(3)</font></b> First 64 KB RAM bank (8x4164 chips)<br> <b><font color="#666666">(4)</font></b> Same 6845 video controller as the 48 & 96 versions<br> <b><font color="#666666">(5)</font></b> Second 64 KB RAM bank<br> <b><font color="#666666">(6)</font></b> Provision is made for a third 64 KB RAM bank. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OTHER ENGLISH MANUALS</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Nicolas Sapin</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LYNX DOS MANUALS</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Nicolas Sapin</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEIL DE LYNX N°1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oeil de Lynx" was the french magazine dedicated to the Lynx.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Nicolas Sapin</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE MAN BEHIND THE LYNX</strong></font><br><blockquote>After leaving Cambridge university, <b>John Shirref</b> starts building inflatable and portable structures. Then he plays drums with several rock'n'roll bands and starts to be interested in electronics. He is however still going on with his musician and sound engineer career, before he creates the Lynx. <br><br> Finaly, after the Lynx adventure, he would goes back to electronic music research...</blockquote>
